Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.

Name: Mrs. Edith Edward
Address: Box 12, A.A. Post Office Box
Birthplace: Stanley, Pincher Creek County, Sask.

1. INTRODUCTORY HISTORY
   What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1892
   Where did you get your housekeeping? Ashton, Sask.
   Where had you been living before that? England
   For how many people did you prepare meals? 6
   How far was it to your nearest store? 3 miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Twice monthly
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, sugar, salt, tea, fruit, vegetables

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years?
   In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour?
   How much did you use Graham flour?
   Whole wheat flour?
   Was flour milled locally? Yes
   How far away? 30 mi
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats?
   What other grain products did you use?
   Cornmeal? Yes
   Whole wheat? Yes
   Farina? No
   Other? No
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes
   How did you grind it? With the old stone grinder or an ordinary meat grinder.
Dear Mr. Wilson,

I am writing to express my gratitude for your kind assistance in the recent project. Your expertise and dedication have been invaluable throughout the process.

Thank you once again for your support.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]

11. Mention any substantial differences in the preparation of meals in the wilderness days as compared with today.

There just wasn't any variety.

12. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

I still do all my baking except bread. I buy my butter and live in town (for a year). I also buy own chickens and eggs. Buy some breakfast cereals, cornflakes, flour, shredded wheat, cheese, peanut butter. Which by the way came in about 1918-19. We had an old man from the States with us for us and he was always talking about it. We asked our guests and he asked

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

This traveller and finally got us some. We didn't like it but have acquired the taste since. I can and dry corn & corn peas beans etc.

In the really early days we didn't know anything concerning it. We didn't get much till the Americans began to come up from the better farming ports. The U.S. I learned from an American. There was very little livestock and stock was kept for them & heifers & cows till we built up a little surplus. The houses were hard with earth floors and if we got a very hard floor it was very rough but spoken of also with more respect than
hardwood nowadays. They were mostly one room, blue houses where we used to stay and hold services had the well water right in the kitchen, so we were going out in the winter when housekeeping needed water, since we had to use while someone else used her rope to pull up the water.

When potatoes were first grown the farmers gave a banquet and invited the neighbors. Here Potatoes!!!

Then came the electric power both on the farm and on the roads. Our family drove an ox and a cow and he could give the children a drink of milk.

There was no railway into Canada and supplies had to be hauled in from Carlingford Manor, Missouri.

There was very little furniture mostly beds built of poles and straw ticks. We kept a piano the only one for years. Then Dad had a small folding organ that was after 1900. He used to put it in a case he made and strap it on the back of the buggy and how it was appreciated at the various houses we stopped at.

His parish was from Estevan to Gainsborough, Postal to Carlingford Manor. Everyone came to church and it was held just wherever he was, I don't know how the word got around but it did. We got an occasional paper from England.

[Signature]
They were not used mostly in town, but horses were used at a stage and hotel service. And the well water was used in the kitchen to save getting out water from the well. William needed water, so he held the pipe until Emma came back with her hopes to pull up the water.

When potatoes were first grown by farmers, they grew a few and saved them for the winter. When potatoes were saved, they were stored in the cellar. The family would then eat them during the winter months.

The children had a chance to milk cows when there was no railway into Canada and supplies had to be hauled in from Cambridge.

There was only little furniture bought, such as chairs, tables, and chairs. The house was only one story high.

Paul had a small growing organization in his garden after 1900. He used to put it in a box to move and ship it on the train. He bought various flowers in a shop at this time.

This period was from 1875 to 1890. Everyone came to school, but there were few people who attended. It was very hard to keep the school going around that time.

It was an occasional trip from England.
